div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains is $9 to Brindisi. The combined Sea and speical train fare has been reduced to $22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Orotava" will leave Suez about October 6
R.M.S "Ormuz" will leave Suez about Sept,18.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said about July 18
R.M.S. “Ortona" will leave Port Said about August 1
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-905

OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Shropshire 5,730 tons, leaves about September 14.
S.S. Yorkshire 4,700 tons, leaves about September 28.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about September 18.
S.S. Warwickshire 4,196 tons leaves about October 1.

Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

Beau Rivage Hotel. Small Dance. 9.30 p.m.
Khedivah Palace Casino. Reunion des Familles Society’s Ball. 9.30 p.m.
San Stefano Casino. Small Dance. 10 p.m.
A.C.C ground. A.C.C. v. 2nd Royal Berke.Regt.
Esbekieh Theatre. Italian Comedy Company. 9 p.m.
Esbekieh Gardens. Performance by British Military Band. 9 to 11 p.m.
Zoological Gardens. Performance by Ghizeh Boys’ Band in afternoon.
Esbekieh Gardens. Performance by British Military Band. 9 to 11 p.m,

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.

THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.

div.head: RUSSIAN DIPLOMACY
div.p: The diplomatic skill of the Russian Govern¬ment in devising and pushing its plans is, we suspect, a little overrated in Western Europe. It is there believed that St. Peters¬burg is served by hundreds of able and uns¬crupulous agen s, who all pull together, and all carry out far reaching plans, which they do not talk about, but thoroughly understand. The Russian Government is, therefore, it is alleged, successful beyond all other Govern¬ments, so successful that any whisper of its future plans of aggrandisement, even when badly authenticated, sometimes causes a flutter among the nations. Russia, it is said, never, even if defeated, gives up her purpo¬ses ; and as she has no Parliament to distract her, and no diplomatists can contend with her agents in aubtlety and foresight, sba almost always succeeds in them. The result is a widely diffused alarm, and a consequent exaltation of the Russian repute for ability, which of itself increases the weight of Russia in the councils of the world. The facts, however, if carefully observed, do not bear out these pessimistic opinions. Russia, it is true, has spread far and fast in Northern Asia, where there was nothing strong enough to resist her, and where, it must in justice be added, her administration, though always too daa- potio, and occasionally violent and cruel, is distinctly better through long terms of years than the administrations it superseded. Bnt she has not succeeded at all strikingly in making herself a "world-Power.” She She has feared to colonise any place divided from herself by the sea. She has not, after a century of effort, broken her way to open water yet. She has not conquered Constantinople, and her land road to it is as solidly barred as ever. Bhe has, by permitting the conversion of Germany from a loosely knit Federation into a strongly knit military Empire, immeasurably reduced her own influence in Europe ; has, indeed, compelled hmelf to lean for safety on an ally whose thoughts are not her thought®, and whose objects ere aaaeawily Inn in Aab ab hm oonpQad India to strengthen herself so greatly that an invasion from the North is most difficult; and goaded Japan into fighting her before she herself was nearly ready to repel and punish the assault. She has driven England, which at heart dis- likes fettering alliances, into a close alliance with the most formidable enemy of Russia on he Pacific ; has at the same time, by a series of amazing blunders, alienated the strong sym¬pathy formerly felt for her. in the United States ; and has forced the strongest and most united of clans, the world-wide Jewish people, with its controlling influence over finance and journalism, to become her irreconcilable foe. These can hardly be called successes, even if we refrain from comparing Russian diplo- matists and statesmen with Bismarck and Cavour, each of whom won for his master each splendid triumphs ; and the successive occu¬pants of the Russian Foreign Office have failed at another point which may prove hereafter of ever greater importance. They have failed in securing the confidence of the world, or even of that section of it whose ideas march fairly well with their own. We do not our¬selves believe, as most of our countrymen do, that this loss is a deserved, We see no reason for believing that falsity is imbedded in the Russian character, or that her diplomat¬ists despise a rigid adherence to truth more than the majority of their profession. Russia keeps European treaties fairly well, and has once or twice exhibited in difficult circumstance a fidelity to pecuniary engagements at once praiseworthy in itself and profitable to her credit We should have said that the innate Russian fault was a violent aggreesive- ness of demeanour rather than a silken falsity like that of the Byzantines. Bat it is mere matter of fact that her agents have in one way or another created a nearly universal distrust in her sincerity, and that this distrust hampers and burdens her at every turn. It was really disbelief in Russian promises which induced Japan to stake her existence as an independent Power upon the ohanoea of a long, exhausting, and most com plicated war. But for distrust as to the security of the “open door,” Russia might have almost a free hand in settling the destiny of China. But for a suspicion which, jnst or unjust, seems irremovable, Great Britain and Russia would long ago have come to an agree¬ment about influence in Asia which would, to say the least of it, have reduced their financial hardens in that continent by one-half. It is Russia's indefiniteness as to pledgee, to use the most polite expression, which prevents the world from securing for her the o]ear water¬way to the Mediterranean which she very naturally thinks her right Let Russia but convince the world that she intends to go straight, and her career, even if it is still a career of conquest, will be smoothed for her in every direction. Nobody wants to keep her away from the water out of pare spite ; bat then nobody believes what her agents, who are struggling to clear the road to the water for her, say or promise. To what, then, are we to ascribe the ten¬dency of successive Russian Governments to inspire a distrust which, so far from streng-thening, cripples them I They must know that it is an obstacle, and why do they allow it to grow np ! In part, no donbt, it is due to the fact that under an obscurantist autocracy it is the unscrupulous who most frequently rise to the top ; but it is also in part due to a very curious failure within the autocracy itself. Every one in Western Europe thinks of the Russian agents as slaves to a central Com¬mittee ; but in reality the Russian Govern¬ment gives its agents more of a free hand than is enjoyed by those of any other European Power. It leaves to its Ambassadors and Vice- a liberty as complete as it claims for it¬self, refuses to fetter them with detailed “instructions,” and requires of them nothing but success. Sometimes, when the agents are able and dreamstanoes are favourable, that policy succeeds; and sometimes, when, as often happens, they are stupid cr obstinate men, it fails; but always it leaves to oompa* ratively irresponsible men too much power, and always it tempts them to make promises and sign arrangements which the ultimate authority is obliged more or less decisively to repudiate. The agents are, of course, eager for approval at home, and they are also eager to be, and to appear to be, great personages at their stations. They straggle for sucess, they grow jealous of each other, they try to make everything pleasant to St. Petersburg, till their Government, there is reason to believe, often grows bewildered by the information oonveyed, and a sort of contest springs up between the delegating authority and the authorities who are delegated. There is an incoherence in their action which at once suggests to the observe* —who, be it remembered, is full of distrust— that somebody is cheating, or hiding truths, or making promises which it is not inten ded to keep. It is dear, for example even from the very imperfect revelations that have reached the general ear, that a struggle of thia kind occurred between St Petersburg and the Viceroy of the Far East; that the Tsar in tended a compromise while his Viceroy tend¬ed either to secure a grand diplomatic victory or to force a war, the result being that the Japanese thought that they were being amused while preparations went on,'and at last refused to be delayed any longer. Could they have trusted their antagonists, they might have assented to an arrangement which would at least have postponed war for five years ; but with Admiral Alexeieff saying one thing and the Foreign Office another, they at last came to disbelieve both, aud stuck for their own interests exclusively. England regarded the whole affair as proof positive at once of Russian aggressiveness and Russian duplicity bat the loose system through which the autocracy works is at least as much to blame as any inherent duplicity in the Russian character, os any quality of excessiveness in Russian ambition.

div.head: THE , EGYPTIAN , GAZETTE, MONDAY,,,.SEPTEMBER. 41, 4905
TIIE CAUCASIAN REVOLT,
£20,000,000 DAMAGES-
BRITISH SUBJECTS SAFE,
div.p: ST. PETEBSBUBQ, September 9. The latest telegrams from the Caucasus are vague and confused. It is impossible to say whether the rising is spreading or subsiding. Against the reassuring official telegrams, there are private messages recounting wholesale massacres of Armenians. It is feared that the four British subjects at Balakhany have been shot or perished in the flames. (fiswtw) BAKU, September 9. The Armenian Bishop at Shusha telegraphs an appalling account of the devastation there. The town is a mass of rains. The fighting between the Tartars and the Armenians lasted five days. Hundreds of killed and wounded are lying in the streets. He appeals for aid for the starving people who number thousands. It is estimated that the actual destruction to the oil industry at Baku involves a direct loss of £20,000,000, while it will require several millions to restore the workings. In addition there will be immense losses to the Russian industries using naphtha as a fuel. (BsalsrJ ST. PETEBSBUBO, September 9. It is annonnoed from Baku that the damages caused by the fires are estimated at 500,000,000 francs, and that in the fights between the Tartars and Armenians 1,500 people have been killed. (Ham) BAKU, September 10. The Vice-Consul telegraphs that all the British subjects are safe. (Reuter)

div.head: THE) EARTHQUAKE IN ITALY.
2,500 KILLED.
THOUSANDS HOMELESS.
ROME, September 9.
div.p: The Government is taking special measures to relieve the terrible distress caused by the earthquake The soldiers have laboured unceasingly in the work or rescue- Thousands are homeless. The mortality is still undetermined. (Reuter)

CATANZABO, September 10. The latest reports regarding the earthquake show that 300 persons were killed at Fargheli, 200 at Japplo and 2000 killed and injured at Martirano. Fresh shocks took place at Reggio di Calabria yesterday afternoon. The population was panic stricken. (B.) ROME, September 10. The Kaiser and M. Lonbet have telegraphed their condolences to the King on the disasters in Calabria. (Bam)

div.head: MARQUESS OF LONDONDERRY'S SPEECH.
. THE ANGLO-JAPANESE TREATY.
div.p: LONDON, September 10. The Marquess of Londonderry, speaking at Stockton, extolled the Japanese magnanimity in the peace settlement, and declared that the Anglo-Japanese treaty was of great benefit to the whole world.

div.head: FRANCE AND GERMANY.
NEGOTIATIONS BEGUN.
div.p: PARIS, September 9. M. Rosen has commenced negotiations with M. Rouvier regarding Moroccoo. (Reuter.)

div.head: EXPLOSION AT UNIONSTOWN.
THE TOKIO RIOT.
TOWN SETTLING DOWN.
BARON KATSURA'S STATEMENTS.
div.p: TOKIO, September 9. At an informal meeting of the members of the Parliament, Baron Katsnra made a reas¬suring statement showing that Japan has not agreed not to fortify the La Perouse Straits, but only guaranteed a free passage. He also stated that Japan, acquires a free hand in Korea. The Minister of Marine emphasized the fact that the capture of Vladivostok would have demanded greater sacrifices than those at Port Arthur. These statements have tended to quieten the people. (Rssiisr) TOKIO, September 10. The town is settling down in consequence of reassuring official statements. No farther dis¬orders are feared. The Guards at the Foreign Legations have been withdrawn. It is believed that the Government will resign when the Diet meets. (Reuter)

div.head: THE POBIEDONOSET’S MUTINEERS.
! SEVENTY-FIVE SENTENCED.
div.p: ST. PETEBSBURG, September 9. The Court martial on the mutineers of the Pobiedonoset’s crew condemned 3 of them to death, 19 to penal servitude, and 33 to disci¬plinary work. Twenty were acquitted. (Reuter) ODESSA, September 9. Seventy five of the Pobiedonosets mutineers have been sentenced, three of them to death. (Sosos;

div.head: ARMISTICE IN MANCHURIA.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, September 10. The armistice in Manchuria has come into force. (Ham)

div.head: THE CHOLERA EPIDEMIC.
139 CASES, 46 DEATHS.
div.p: BEBLIN, September 10. The official bulletin reports up to the present 189 cases of cholera and 46 deaths. (H.)

div.head: KING EDWARD RETURNS.
div.p: LONDON, September 9. The King has arrived here. *

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: CONSTANTINOPLE; September 1O. The Khedive has arrived here. (Reuter)

div.head: ELGIN ELECTION.
div.p: LONDON, September 10. Mr. Sutherland, Liberal, 2,474 votes. Mr. Roseiness, Unionist, polled 1,021. (Reuter)

div.head: THE SERVIAN THRONE.
div.p: BELGRADE, September 9. The majority of the Crown Prince has been proclaimed. (Reuter

div.head: EGYPT AND ITALY.
div.p: The Royal Commission which has recently been enquiring into the condition of the Italian mercantile marine has made the following suggestions to the Italian Government which relate to sea communication between Egypt and Italy. (1) To create a direct fast weekly service, Genoa—Naples — Alexandria, carried on by 19 knot boats of 7,000 metric tons displacement. (2) A direct fast weekly service between Venice—Brindisi—Alexandria, carried on by large 19 knot steamers. (8) A fortnightly service from Genoa to Leghorn, Naples, Messina, Tunis, Tripoli, Alexandria, the Syrian porta, and Venice, and vice versa. This service would be weekly at Alexandria, one boat arriving every week from Venice and one from Genoa.

div.head: LOCAL AND'GENERAL
div.p: STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS found in the iZeitonn district of Cairo daring to-morrow and at dawn of the 13th inst. will be poisoned by the police.

KILLED BY A CART.—A native boy, ten years of age, named Mahmoud Ali El Gamal, was inn over by a cart at Karmons yesterday, and received severe internal injuries from which he shortly expired. The driver of the cart was arrested.

SAD DROWNING FATALITY. — We greatly regret to announce that whilst Sheikh Moha¬med Haronn, Grand Cadi of the Sudan, and his family were returning to Haifa from Assouan by steamer, his little daughter fell overboard and was drowned. The body of the ohild has not been recovered.

SUEZ CANAL,—Nine ships passed through the canal on Friday, paying in dues frs. 287,140.96. Of these five were English, one German, one French, one Italian, and 1 Austri¬an. The receipts from 89 ships which have passed through between the 1st, and 8th September amount to frs. 2,846,293.94.

SALT AND SODA COMPANY.—The monthly returns of the Egyptian Salt and Soda Co. Ltd. show that the sales daring last month amounted to L.E. 17,669.253 as against L.K 16,988,779 daring August 1904. Since the 1st January the total sales amount to L.E. 170,944.617 as against L.E. 169,210.380 during the corresponding last year.

THB CHOLERA IN FRANCE. —The President of the Quarantine Board has received a com¬munication from the French Sanitary delegate informing him that there is no cholera at Brest. Two suspected cases occured in that town and in a neighbouring locality but on being subjected to bacteriological examination no reaction was given.

THE EGYPTIAN ARMY.—El Bimbashi F. C. Heneker, Sndan Government has resigned his commission on the strength of the Egyptian Army. El Bimbashi H. W. Channer, 3rd Battalion, has been transferred to the Sudan Govern v enf. El Bimbashi Hon. W. A. Trefnsis, Aide-de-Camp to H. E. the Sirdar, has been transferred to the 8rd Battalion, and the former appointment will in future be held by El Bimbashi R. J. Collins, 15th Sudanese. El Bimbashi W. B. C Bridge, 11th Sudanese has been transferred to the 9th Sudanese.

BUBONIC PLAGUE.—Nine cases of plague were notified during the week ending last Saturday, of which one occured at Port Said and the remaining eight at Alexandria. The Port Said case ended fatally and there were also three deaths at Alexandria. No cure is reported for the whole week. Twelve cases were remaining under treatment at the end of the week, of which ten were at Alexandria, one at Damietta, and one at Assouan. Since the 1st January there have been 255 cases as against 795 during the corresponding period last year. Sunday’s bulletin reports two reco-veries at Alexandria.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: We are informed that the Earl of Cromer is leaving Marseilles by the P. and 0, steamer Moldavia due at Port Said on the 18th October.
Mr. H. Boyle, Oriental Secretary at the British Agency, has arrived in Cairo.
Dr. Grumprecht; German Consul at Cairo, left for Europe on Saturday. Herr von Veraen, German Consul at Salonica, arrived on Thors day at Cairo and will replace Dr. Grumprecht daring his absence.

We are authorised to contradict the rumour spread lately by several of the Cairo vernacular papers that Lewa Lord Cecil Pasha, D.S.O., is to replace Sir R. Wingate as Sirdar, the latter retaining only the functions of Governor General of the Sudan.
Judge Harold A. Perry is leaving Marseilles on the 22nd inst by the Bibby liner Yorkshire.
lady Mollwraith is taking passage by the P. and O.'Moldavia, leaving London on the 6th October.
Mr. and Mrs. Lang Anderson and the Misses Anderson are likewise returning by the P. and 0. S.S. Moldavia.
We regret to announce the sudden death of Mr. S. Felice, which occured at Vienna on the 2nd inst, while the deceased was returning to Egypt from Marienbad.
Idris Bey Ragheb arrived at Alexandria yesterday by the Florio-Rubbattino mail boat
Mr. William Kay Marr has been provision ally appointed to the 3rd Circle of Irrigation as engineer on a monthly salary of £80.
Bimbashi R. J. Collins of the 15th Sudance, has been appelated A.D.C. to HR the-Birdee.
The General Manager reports that the em bankment and approach for the junction of the Nile Khargeh line with the Egyptian State Railway is now completed.

div.head: SIR WILLIAM GARSTIN ON UPPER ’NILE PROBLEMS.
div.p: Sir William Garstin in his: article entitled “Some problems of the Upper Nile" which has recently appeared ; in the September Nineteenth Century, and After,’’ after a most interesting description of the part played by the different rivers which together form the Nile, and a picturesque account of their prin¬cipal features, points out that by 1908, two and a half million seres of land in Egypt will require to be provided with perennial irriga¬tion. (Te most thin need five million of cobio metres of water must be stored. The Assouan dam will, perhaps, not be raised, and the Wadi Rayan will probably be left till »such time are the question of reclaim¬ing and irrigating the shallowlakes of, the Northern Delta shall,become one- of urgency,Farther storage of water, even if, the Assouan dam were raised, (would injure winter, navign tion on the Nila between Assouan and Cairo in. a year of low supply and would only furnish a partial solution of the problem. The extra water required can only be obtained by in- creasing the flow of,the Upper Nile during winter, spring, and early summer. Sir William Garstin then describes the scheme suggested by Mr. J. E. Beresford, late Impastor General of legation in India for the construction of a new Channel between Bor and the Sohat junction. The scheme would oertainly enable the whole summer discharge of the white Nile to reach Tewfi kieh with the minimum of loss, the marshes being used to receive the flood overflow. This new channel would be 322 miles in' length, while if the Bahr el Zeraf were cleared and freed of obstructions the distance from Bor to Tewfikieh would still be 498 miles,, and if the Bahr el Gebel was used it would be fifty-two miles longer. As regards distance the advantages of the Beresford's scheme are great, but the author points out that there are two difficulties; its possibly prohibitive cost owing to diffi¬cult levels which surveys may yet discover, and the practical difficulties in the way of actually constructing the channel. At the same time a regulator should be constructed near the outlet of the Albert Lake, as Sir William Willoooks has long urged, to secure permanency of supply in the river. Its cons¬truction is in Sir William Garstin's opinion ' the key to the whole question of the impro¬vement of the Upper Nile." Taming to the Bine Nile, the question of a Tsana reservoir cannot be discussed owing to the immense political difficulties connected therewith, and it is a little doubtful whether a suitable site for a Blue Nile reservoir exists in Anglo Egyptian territory. Perennial irriga¬tion in the Sudan south of Khartoum must for the present be abandoned, and all future schemes must almost certainly be devoted to the study of the improvement of winter and flood irrigation. Weirs will have to be constructed between Khartoum and Roeaires, and would be accompanied .by. a system of basins and distributory canals, Such basins might reduce the risk of flood in the Northern Nile valley in “high Nile” years. MISSIONARIES FOR THE SUDAN. THE CRONIES FAILURE.

div.head: ‘THE EFFECT ON THE D'EGYPTE.
div.p: The Church Missionary Society have com¬pleted plans for inaugurating a mission in the Sudan, and with that object in view are despatching on Ootober 19 three missionaries, a doctor, and two specially qualified industrial instructors. They are the Rev. F.B. Hadow, M.A., the Rev. A.Shaw, M.A., and the Rev. A.M. Thom, M.A, Mr. E. Lloyd, and Messrs. J. Comley, and R.C J.8. Wilmot. The society, it is understood, have recieved a cerdial joint invitation from Lord Cromer and the Sudan Government.

div.head: THE CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT, LIMITED.
div.p: The General Manager reports that the embankment and approach for the junction of the Nile Khargeh line with the Egyptain State Railroad is now completed.

div.head: THIRTY-FIVE PEOPLE BURIED.
WASHINGTON, September 10.
div.p: A tremendous explosion destroyed the powder works at Unionstown (Pennsylvania). 35 persons were buried in the ruins. (Reuter) BARON KAMURA ILL PORTSMOUTH (N.H.), September 10. Baron Kamura has been suddenly taken ill with intestinal trouble.

div.head: HOME SPORT.
div.p: LONDON, September 9. Golt. Vardon and Taylor beat Braid and Herd in the great international foursome played at St Andrews; Troon, St Anne’s and Deal, by 18 holes up and 12 to play. Cricket. The match between Mr. C.L Thorn¬ton's XI and the Australians was abandoned.

div.head: ARISITON AERATED WATERS
div.p: Guaranteed Distilled CAIRO I ALEXANDRIA

div.head: BECK and CO'S PILSENER BEER
div.p: Obtainable from every Responsible Firm la Cairo, Alexandria A mfnu

div.head: EGYPTIAN ENGINEERING CO., UMlTJan
div.p: Registered August 28th, by Cramp, Sprott and Co., 6, Great George Street, Westminster, S.W. Capital, £11,000, in 200 “A” shares of £50 each and 200 “B" shares of £5 each. Objects : To carry on the business of agents for the sale of British and other machinery, engineering requisites, manufactures, articles and other goods and merchandise in Egypt and the Sudan, and the business, of mann facturers of and dealers in such goods. No initial public issue. The signatories are to ap¬point the first directors. Qualification, £250. Registered office, Broad Sanctuary Chambers, 20 Tothill Street, Westminster, S.W.

div.head: THE RECAPTURE OF SANA.
div.p: The latest reports from the Yemen show that the success of Ahmed Pari Pasha was due to the astonishing courage with which his troops repeatedly rushed formidably en- trenched positions with the bayonet in the face of a very heavy fire. The actions at Suk el Khamis, Mufhak, and Kamlan were all decided by these offensive tactics, though the veteran Marshal was denied the farther reinforcement of 25,000 men which he demanded, and might well have feared to risk heavy losses. The total Turkish force in the province is now estimated et 45,000 man.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p:
The Moes liner Tabor arrived yesterday from Liverpool, via Gibraltar and
with mafia, and general Paris, September 5th. No sooner was M. Cronies buried than those interested in the Say concern and in the Sucreries d' Egypte went to work to examine the situation, and to see what1 remedies' could be found to save the existence, at least, of the former venture. Apparently all efforts will be concentrated to that end, so that the concentration of the production in which thousands of people are engaged ought not to be stopped one moment. M. Peytel (the managing director of the Credit Algerian)' has meanwhile been entrusted with the duties' of'Chairman of the Sav Company and M. Pelissier with those of technical director of the factories. It is not likely that M. Peytel, who in- recent years has been one of the busiest' of bank directors, would definitely, sesame the sucession of M. Oronier. As to the Sucreries of Egypte, - repre¬sentatives of the banks holding the notorious bills signed by the late' M. Gronier1—notably,' the “Ronvier” Bank, the Union Parisignne, the Austrian Laiderbank, and Messrs. Hindi have met and discussed the state of affairs with the directors of this Franco-Egyptian venture, in which, moreover, English capital is largely interested. No definite resolution has been adopted besides that to "urgently convence a general meeting of the shareholders, which will take place at Cairo.'The secretary of the company his already left for that place, to prepare'eventually measures for a- “conooidat" according to Egyptian company law, which, in any case, would be more pro¬fitable to the shareholders than a winding-up under French legislation. If certain statements are to be credited, the consolidation of the Sudrsries d' Egypte is indeed fraught with great and complicated difficulties. The Societe dee Raffiheries et Snoreriee d'Egypte is really an emalgamatioh of the various sugar concern formerly belong¬ing to the Daira Banish, and; according to its statutes, has to pay to the latter an annuity of 2,030,421 fra. The inability to pay, this amount would necessarily lead to a declaration of bankruptcy. It is in that direction, there¬fore, that the board will have to use all its endeavours. On the other hand, Hear from a' well-informed source; 17 out of the 18 banks which were reported to hold bills signed by M. -Grenier, and due- on September 1, had consented * to a moratorium, -and the' Banque Russo'Chinoise alone refused'to adhere to this arrange cut - Strong appeals -here made to the Russian Government to urge upon the director! of the Russo- Chimsed Bank to change their attitude. ‘ A point'iwhich also required etosidatioa has now been made clear. It was said at first that it was a request of the flay family to render accounts of the treat money- which drove1 M. Csenier to commit suicide. The real and direct cause, however, was that M. Oronier was unable to -settle a bill for 1,000,OOOfra, which matured on the fatal Saturday with the Anglo-Egypt Bank. • As we go to press we receive a telegram from our London correspondent informing M that Malta Carton de Wiart left London on Friday and will arrive at early-on Wednesday morning. Maltre Carton de Wiart’a advanced return to Egypt is connected with the Sucraries situation.

div.head: SEVERAL PERSONS STARRED.
div.p: Shortly Greek orchestra of tile Windsor. I seem to have shown rone intention till d’orchestre, who was when he drew a knife a the musician, stabbed him from the neck and shoulder. confusion followed. The wounded man, according to some, accounts, or one of his companonion accoriding to others, broke a violin over the assailant's head, .people hither and thither in a wild panic and the fact that the would-be murderer flourished his . knife,; and announced his intention in stabbing anyone who laid hands or him de¬terred those present from stopping him before he left the tent. Once outside the tent Agoao made off at remarkable speed the Cafe d’Afrique. Several individuals who tried to stop him were promptly stabbed, though their injuries were in no case severe. Once safely past the cafe the culprit turned into’ the aide alleys, where there are no police; and twisting and dodging at fall, speed disap¬peared from view. ’ The mamour of the Attarin hfaB. i to the spot end had already opened an en¬quiry when Cobbe Bey, the ' dant of Police was communicicated with. An agent was sent to San Stefano, another watched Agoeo'a house in Mehaneas Bay, and others search for the criminal thoughout the town. Meanwhile something like a panic prevailed many of those who had witnessed the outrage and Bemhefhl Cobbe while driving to the Attarin carocol was approached by several agitated. whose fears were calmed by him hat every measure had been to arrest the criminal. At 9.80p.m. j to his house and found a secret waiting for him. He drew a revolver and attempted to blow out his brains. The atanioide failed and Agoan was carried to the Government hospital. On arrival, he was found to be intoxicatded and to have a bullet embedded in his skill which was immediately ekUteted He is now doing well The wounded musician, Pietro Dattftowfu, and the other four persons injured will in no case require more6than seven days faettMrt. It appears . that Mr. Danflohiti had suddenly made a complaint to the British OoMdett against Agoeo who had threatened him on several occasions. The criminal is a British subject and will appeal before the-Consalar Court as soon as he has recovered from his self-inflicted injuries. With a view - to preventing the of similar crimes and the temporary of their perpetrators in the dusk 1 fall, the acting Commandant of Porch Police orders that ghaffin shall parade in 1 7 pm. instead of 8 p.m. in* the I et" 6 pm. instead of 7 p.m. in the winter months. The decision seems to eminently sound one, end we acting Commandant and the I the expedition with' which they arrested a most dangerous and irrespnosible aooahdrtl, The S.S. Tebe leaves Genoa today with sixty Italian delegates on board, who will attend the Colonial conference which is to be held at Asmara, the mountain station which is the sanatorium for the colony of Eritrea The Tebe arrives here next Sunday and .will start for the Canal and Massowah next day. On their return from the congress the delegates will land at' Suez and pass ten -days or so at Cairo.
